pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 186, 170, 200]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 206, 280, 221]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 248, 600, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 386, 327]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 343, 235, 356]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 371]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 890, 400]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 382, 414]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 890, 458]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 890, 473]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 555, 503]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 764, 530]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 532, 416, 546]]<|/det|>
Any working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 547, 359, 561]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 87]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 919, 121]]<|/det|> The radius of the Earth is approximately \(6.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) , and the radius of the Moon is approximately \(1.7 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\) . A student wishes to build a scale model of the Solar System in the classroom, using a football of radius \(0.12 \text{m}\) to represent the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 497, 151]]<|/det|> Which object would best represent the Moon? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 240, 179]]<|/det|> A basketball <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 208, 205]]<|/det|> B cherry <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 216, 222, 231]]<|/det|> C golf ball <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 240, 256]]<|/det|> D tennis ball <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 286, 96, 303]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 920, 317]]<|/det|> When a beam of light is incident on a surface, it delivers energy to the surface. The intensity of the beam is defined as the energy delivered per unit area per unit time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 332, 584, 348]]<|/det|> What is the unit of intensity, expressed in SI base units? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 360, 703, 376]]<|/det|> A \(\mathsf{kg}\mathsf{m}^{- 2}\mathsf{s}^{- 1}\) B \(\mathsf{kg}\mathsf{m}^2\mathsf{s}^{- 3}\) C \(\mathsf{kg}\mathsf{s}^{- 2}\) D \(\mathsf{kg}\mathsf{s}^{- 3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 406, 96, 424]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 406, 750, 422]]<|/det|> A ship is travelling with a velocity of \(8.0 \text{km} \text{h}^{- 1}\) in a direction \(30^{\circ}\) east of north. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 437, 772, 453]]<|/det|> What are the components of the ship's velocity in the east and north directions? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 466, 585, 626]]<|/det|>
component of velocity in east direction
/km h-1		component of velocity in north direction
/km h-1
A4.04.0
B4.06.9
C4.66.9
D6.94.0

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 750, 90]]<|/det|> A micrometer screw gauge is used to measure the diameter of a copper wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 919, 135]]<|/det|> The reading with the wire in position is shown in diagram 1. The wire is removed and the jaws of the micrometer are closed. The new reading is shown in diagram 2. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 144, 789, 293]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 390, 324]]<|/det|> What is the diameter of the wire? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 725, 352]]<|/det|> **A** 1.90 mm **B** 2.45 mm **C** 2.59 mm **D** 2.73 mm <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 380, 96, 399]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 445, 396]]<|/det|> A digital meter has an accuracy of \(\pm 1\%\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 411, 641, 427]]<|/det|> The meter is used to measure the current in an electrical circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 441, 610, 457]]<|/det|> The reading on the meter varies between 3.04 A and 3.08 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 471, 549, 487]]<|/det|> What is the value of the current, with its uncertainty? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 277, 516]]<|/det|> **A** (3.06 ± 0.02)A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 528, 277, 543]]<|/det|> **B** (3.06 ± 0.04)A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 277, 570]]<|/det|> **C** (3.06 ± 0.05)A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 277, 598]]<|/det|> **D** (3.06 ± 0.07)A <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 625, 96, 644]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 625, 686, 642]]<|/det|> A tennis ball is thrown horizontally in air from the top of a tall building. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 655, 484, 671]]<|/det|> The effect of air resistance is **not** negligible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 685, 809, 701]]<|/det|> What happens to the horizontal and to the vertical components of the ball's velocity? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 715, 706, 858]]<|/det|>
horizontal component of velocityvertical component of velocity
Aconstantconstant
Bconstantincreases at a constant rate
Cdecreases to zeroincreases at a constant rate
Ddecreases to zeroincreases to a maximum value

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 106]]<|/det|> Water is pumped through a hose-pipe at a rate of \(90\mathrm{kg}\) per minute. Water emerges horizontally from the hose-pipe with a speed of \(20\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 919, 150]]<|/det|> What is the minimum force required from a person holding the hose-pipe to prevent it moving backwards? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 160, 739, 177]]<|/det|> **A** 30N **B** 270N **C** 1800N **D** 108000N <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 206, 96, 223]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 919, 238]]<|/det|> A ball of mass \(m\) is thrown vertically into the air. When the ball has speed \(v\), the air resistance acting on the ball is \(F\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 250, 914, 267]]<|/det|> What is the magnitude of the acceleration of the ball when its speed is \(v\) as it rises and as it falls? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 561, 517]]<|/det|>
acceleration when ball is risingacceleration when ball is falling
A\(g-\frac {F}{m}\)\(g-\frac {F}{m}\)
B\(g-\frac {F}{m}\)\(g+\frac {F}{m}\)
C\(g+\frac {F}{m}\)\(g-\frac {F}{m}\)
D\(g+\frac {F}{m}\)\(g+\frac {F}{m}\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 548, 96, 565]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 548, 668, 565]]<|/det|> What is a statement of the principle of conservation of momentum? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 577, 141, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 830, 594]]<|/det|> A force is equal to the rate of change of momentum of the body upon which it acts. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 603, 141, 621]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 603, 919, 635]]<|/det|> In a perfectly elastic collision, the relative momentum of the bodies before impact is equal to their relative momentum after impact. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 644, 141, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 811, 661]]<|/det|> The momentum of a body is the product of the mass of the body and its velocity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 670, 141, 688]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 670, 919, 702]]<|/det|> The total momentum of a system of interacting bodies remains constant, providing no resultant external force acts on the system.

fieldcharge on particle

A rocket is fired upwards.

As it accelerates upwards after leaving the launch pad, which forms of energy are changing?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 469, 693, 486]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 495, 607, 512]]<|/det|>

A mass \(m\) is on top of a platform that is supported by gas in a cylinder of cross-sectional area \(A\), as shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 117, 618, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 255, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
The platform has negligible mass and can move freely up and down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 920, 320]]<|/det|>
The gas is heated and expands so that the mass is raised through a height \(h\). Atmospheric pressure is \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 668, 350]]<|/det|>
What is the ratio \(\frac{\text{gain in gravitational potential energy of the mass }}{\text{work done by the gas}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 390, 136, 408]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 387, 732, 419]]<|/det|>
\(mg\) \(\mathbf{B}\) \(\frac{mg}{mg + pA}\) \(\mathbf{C}\) \(\frac{pA}{mg}\) \(\mathbf{D}\) \(\frac{mg - pA}{mg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 135]]<|/det|>
An 8.00 N weight is attached to the lower end of a spring which is fixed at its upper end. The weight is initially held at rest at position X and the spring is unstretched. The weight is then released and falls to position Y, which is 4.00 cm below X. The weight oscillates and then eventually comes to rest at O, which is 2.00 cm below X.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 141, 750, 504]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 517, 468, 534]]<|/det|>
How much energy is lost from the system?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 707, 562]]<|/det|>
**A** 0.04J **B** 0.08J **C** 0.16J **D** 0.32J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 592, 107, 610]]<|/det|>
<label>17</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 592, 919, 624]]<|/det|>
The force resisting the motion of a car is proportional to the square of the car's speed. The magnitude of the force at a speed of \(20.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) is 800 N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 636, 920, 668]]<|/det|>
What useful output power is required from the car's engine to maintain a steady speed of \(40.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\)?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 680, 141, 698]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 680, 207, 698]]<|/det|>
32kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[282, 680, 374, 698]]<|/det|>
B 64kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 680, 551, 698]]<|/det|>
C 128kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 680, 718, 698]]<|/det|>
D 512kW

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 919, 120]]<|/det|>
Two wires X and Y are made from the same material. Wire Y has twice the diameter and experiences twice the tension of wire X. The wires obey Hooke's law and have the same original length.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[307, 131, 688, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 383, 315, 399]]<|/det|>
Wire X has extension e.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 384, 430]]<|/det|>
What is the extension of wire Y?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 680, 470]]<|/det|>
A \(\frac{e}{4}\) B \(\frac{e}{2}\) C e D \(2e\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 500, 107, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 500, 919, 532]]<|/det|>
What is represented by the gradient of a graph of force (vertical axis) against extension (horizontal axis) for a wire obeying Hooke's law?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 543, 250, 559]]<|/det|>
A elastic limit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 282, 585]]<|/det|>
B spring constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 596, 207, 610]]<|/det|>
C stress

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 622, 285, 636]]<|/det|>
D Young modulus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Forces are applied to the ends of a rod so that its length increases. The variation with load \(L\) of the extension \(e\) of the rod is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 115, 625, 252]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 267, 364, 284]]<|/det|>
The point P is the elastic limit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 297, 835, 314]]<|/det|>
Which shaded area represents the work done during the plastic deformation of the rod?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 472, 107, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 472, 919, 504]]<|/det|> A jet aircraft travels at a speed of \(0.8v\) where \(v\) is the speed of sound. The aircraft approaches a stationary observer. The frequency of sound emitted by the aircraft is \(100 \text{Hz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 464, 534]]<|/det|> Which frequency does the observer hear? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 546, 714, 562]]<|/det|> A 56 Hz B 180 Hz C 400 Hz D 500 Hz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 592, 107, 610]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 592, 825, 608]]<|/det|> A telescope detects and analyses some electromagnetic radiation of wavelength 2 cm. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 622, 360, 638]]<|/det|> Which type of telescope is it? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 651, 332, 666]]<|/det|> A microwave telescope <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 677, 293, 692]]<|/det|> B optical telescope <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 704, 282, 718]]<|/det|> C radio telescope <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 728, 285, 743]]<|/det|> D X-ray telescope <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 772, 107, 790]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 520, 788]]<|/det|> What may be used to produce stationary waves? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 800, 500, 816]]<|/det|> A blowing air over the top of an empty bottle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 827, 465, 842]]<|/det|> B making a loud sound near a mountain <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 853, 562, 868]]<|/det|> C passing monochromatic light through a double slit <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 879, 504, 894]]<|/det|> D passing water waves through a narrow slit

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>27</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 515, 90]]<|/det|>
What is an example of the diffraction of a wave?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 140, 119]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 101, 475, 119]]<|/det|>
laser light travelling along an optic fibre

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 144, 145]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 127, 546, 144]]<|/det|>
light waves forming images on a cinema screen

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 154, 139, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 154, 532, 170]]<|/det|>
microwaves passing the edge of a metal plate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 547, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 179, 547, 195]]<|/det|>
sound waves diverging as they pass through air

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 107, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 846, 240]]<|/det|>
When the light from two lamps falls on a screen, no interference pattern can be obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 220, 271]]<|/det|>
<pre>Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 430, 299]]<|/det|>
<pre>A The lamps are not point sources.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 310, 515, 325]]<|/det|>
<pre>B The lamps emit light of different amplitudes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 485, 351]]<|/det|>
<pre>C The light from the lamps is not coherent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 362, 426, 377]]<|/det|>
<pre>D The light from the lamps is white.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 405, 107, 424]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 405, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
A beam of light consists of two wavelengths of \(436\mathrm{nm}\) and \(654\mathrm{nm}\) . A diffraction grating of \(5.00\times 10^{5}\) lines \(\mathrm{m}^{- 1}\) produces a diffraction pattern in which the second order of one of these wavelengths occurs at the same angle \(\theta\) as the third order of the other wavelength.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 465, 777, 613]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 292, 645]]<|/det|>
What is the angle \(\theta ?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 657, 148, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 657, 200, 675]]<|/det|>
19.1°

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[294, 657, 380, 675]]<|/det|>
B \(25.8^{\circ}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 657, 546, 675]]<|/det|>
C \(40.8^{\circ}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[606, 657, 700, 675]]<|/det|>
D \(78.8^{\circ}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 704, 868, 720]]<|/det|>
Which diagram shows the electric field lines surrounding an isolated negative point charge?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[165, 731, 831, 853]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 717, 90]]<|/det|>
A beam of electrons is directed into an electric field and is deflected by it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 636, 119]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 represents an electric field in the plane of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 825, 134]]<|/det|>
Diagram 2 represents an electric field directed perpendicular to the plane of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 918, 180]]<|/det|>
The lines **A**, **B**, **C** and **D** represent possible paths of the electron beam. All paths are in the plane of the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 193, 676, 209]]<|/det|>
Which line best represents the path of the electrons inside the field?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 220, 920, 492]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 520, 107, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 520, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
A charged particle of charge \(q\) and mass \(m\) is initially at rest in a uniform electric field. The field is produced by parallel metal plates separated by a distance \(d\) and having a potential difference \(V\) between them.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 581, 663, 597]]<|/det|>
What is an expression for the acceleration of the charged particle?

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 606, 692, 636]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A}\quad \frac{md}{qV}\qquad \mathbf{B}\quad \frac{mV}{qd}\qquad \mathbf{C}\quad \frac{qd}{mV}\qquad \mathbf{D}\quad \frac{qV}{md}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 670, 107, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 670, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
When there is a current of 5.0A in a copper wire, the average drift velocity of the free electrons is \(8.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 717, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
What is the average drift velocity in a different copper wire that has twice the diameter and a current of 10.0A?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 761, 280, 777]]<|/det|>
A \(4.0\times 10^{-4}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 788, 280, 804]]<|/det|>
B \(8.0\times 10^{-4}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 815, 280, 831]]<|/det|>
C \(1.6\times 10^{-3}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 842, 280, 858]]<|/det|>
D \(3.2\times 10^{-3}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 107, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 372, 90]]<|/det|>
What is equivalent to one volt?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 359, 118]]<|/det|>
A one coulomb per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 337, 144]]<|/det|>
B one joule per coulomb

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 327, 170]]<|/det|>
C one joule per second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 179, 475, 196]]<|/det|>
D one joule second per coulomb squared

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 224, 107, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 690, 241]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a rectangular block with dimensions \(x\) , \(2x\) and \(3x\) .

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 252, 755, 444]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 460, 919, 492]]<|/det|>
Electrical contact can be made to the block between opposite pairs of faces (for example, between the faces labelled R).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 737, 522]]<|/det|>
Which statement describing the electrical resistance of the block is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 534, 520, 551]]<|/det|>
A It is maximum between the faces labelled P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 560, 520, 577]]<|/det|>
B It is maximum between the faces labelled Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 587, 520, 603]]<|/det|>
C It is maximum between the faces labelled R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 534, 629]]<|/det|>
D It is the same, whichever pair of faces is used.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[115, 117, 626, 135]]<|/det|>
The resistance of RQ is equal to the resistance of the resistor.
